what: Structural Modeling for Multiple Latent Class Variables
title: Structural Modeling for Multiple Latent Class Variables
text: slca provides comprehensive tools implementation Structural Latent Class Models (SLCM), including Latent Transition Analysis (LTA; Linda M. Collins Stephanie T. Lanza, 2009) doi:10.1002/9780470567333, Latent Class Profile Analysis (LCPA; Hwan Chung et al., 2010) doi:10.1111/j.1467-985x.2010.00674.x, Joint Latent Class Analysis (JLCA; Saebom Jeon et al., 2017) doi:10.1080/10705511.2017.1340844, extended models involving multiple latent class variables.

title: Structural Modeling for Multiple Latent Class Variables
text: can install released version slca CRAN : development version GitHub :
code: install.packages("slca") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("kim0sun/slca")

text: part focuses establishing relationships different latent class variables. example, L1 ~ L2 indicates relationship L1 impact related L2, shown :  cases, might need define higher-level latent class variables influenced comprise several latent class variables. example, higher-level variable P composite L1, L2, L3. , note define number latent classes P. relationship can represented follows:

title: Structural Modeling for Multiple Latent Class Variables
text: critical aspect model specification ensuring measurement invariance. concept refers idea latent construct measured across different groups time points. slca, can assume measurement invariance setting constraints latent class variables. constraints argument used specify latent class variables measured homogeneous manner. feature crucial comparative studies need ensure measurement properties constructs consistent across different sub-groups time. model needs constrained transition probabilities homogeneous, can use ~ -> represent relationships want indicate, follows:

title: Structural Modeling for Multiple Latent Class Variables
code: library(slca) lta <- slca(L1[3] ~ x1 + y1 + z1, L2[3] ~ x2 + y2 + z2, L3[3] ~ x3 + y3 + z3,             L1 ~ L2, L2 ~ L3, constraints = c("L1", "L2", "L3")) plot(lta) jlca <- slca(L1[3] ~ x1 + x2 + x3, L2[3] ~ y1 + y2 + y3, L3[3] ~ z1 + z2 + z3,              JC[3] ~ L1 + L2 + L3) plot(jlca) lcamg <- slca(L1[3] ~ x1 + x2 + x3, L2[3] ~ y1 + y2 + y3, L3[3] ~ z1 + z2 + z3,               JC[3] ~ L1 + L2 + L3, LG[3] ~ g1 + g2 + g3,                LG ~ JC) plot(lcamg)

what: Adolescent Depression Data from the Add Health Study — addhealth
title: Adolescent Depression Data from the Add Health Study — addhealth
text: dataset includes responses National Longitudinal Study Adolescent Health (Add Health), focusing adolescents' experiences depression. subjects, Grades 10 11 1994-1995 academic year, provided data least one measure adolescent delinquency Wave 1. data can used replicate latent class analysis conducted Collins Lanza (2008). dataset includes five covariates, notably grade level sex respondents, along variables capturing depressive emotions: sadness (S1-S4), feeling disliked (D1-D2), feelings failure (F1-F2).

S2w1, S2w2 felt depressed. S3w1, S3w2 felt lonely. S4w1, S4w2 felt sad. D1w1, D1w2 People unfriendly . D2w1, D2w2 felt people disliked F1w1, F1w2 thought life failure. what: Compare Two Estimated slca Models — compare
title: Compare Two Estimated slca Models — compare
text: Provides relative model fit test two fitted SLCM models deviance statistic.

title: Compare Two Estimated slca Models — compare
code: compare(   model1,   model2,   test = c("none", "chisq", "boot"),   nboot = 50,   method = c("hybrid", "em", "nlm"),   plot = FALSE,   maxiter = 1000,   tol = 1e-08,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Compare Two Estimated slca Models — compare
text: model1 object class slca estimated. model2 another object class slca estimated. test character string specifying type test conducted. "chisq", chi-squared test conducted. "boot", bootstrap test conducted. nboot integer specifying number bootstrap rounds performed. method estimation method bootstrapping. plot logical value indicating whether print histogram G-squared statistics boostrap samples, test = "boot". maxiter integer specifying maximum number iterations allowed estimation process bootstrapping round. tol numeric value setting tolerance convergence bootstrapping round. verbose logical value indicating whether print progress updates number bootstrapping rounds completed.

title: Compare Two Estimated slca Models — compare
text: data.frame containing number parameters (Df), loglikelihood, AIC, BIC, G-squared statistics, residual degree freedom object. Depending test argument, p-value corresponding statistical test may also included.

title: Compare Two Estimated slca Models — compare
code: library(magrittr) data <- gss7677[gss7677$COHORT == "YOUNG", ] stat2 <- slca(status(2) ~ PAPRES + PADEG + MADEG) %>%    estimate(data = data, control = list(verbose = FALSE)) stat3 <- slca(status(3) ~ PAPRES + PADEG + MADEG) %>%    estimate(data = data, control = list(verbose = FALSE)) stat4 <- slca(status(4) ~ PAPRES + PADEG + MADEG) %>%    estimate(data = data, control = list(verbose = FALSE))  gof(stat2, stat3, stat4) #> Analysis of Goodness of Fit Table #>  #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC     Gsq Res. Df #> stat2 21 -1179.2 2400.4 2489.5 115.979      53 #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5  36.204      42 #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4  28.423      31 gof(stat2, stat3, stat4, test = "chisq") #> Analysis of Goodness of Fit Table #>  #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC     Gsq Res. Df Pr(>Chi)     #> stat2 21 -1179.2 2400.4 2489.5 115.979      53 1.34e-06 *** #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5  36.204      42   0.7226     #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4  28.423      31   0.5993     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 # \donttest{ gof(stat2, stat3, stat4, test = "boot") #> Analysis of Goodness of Fit Table #>  #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC     Gsq Res. Df Pr(Boot)     #> stat2 21 -1179.2 2400.4 2489.5 115.979      53   <2e-16 *** #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5  36.204      42     0.21     #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4  28.423      31     0.45     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 # }  compare(stat3, stat4) #> Analysis of Relative Model Fit #>  #> Model H0: stat3 #> Model H1: stat4 #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC    Gsq Res. Df #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5                #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4 7.7805      11 compare(stat3, stat4, test = "chisq") #> Analysis of Relative Model Fit #>  #> Model H0: stat3 #> Model H1: stat4 #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC    Gsq Res. Df Pr(>Chi) #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5                         #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4 7.7805      11   0.7328 # \donttest{ compare(stat3, stat4, test = "boot") #> Analysis of Relative Model Fit #>  #> Model H0: stat3 #> Model H1: stat4 #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC    Gsq Res. Df Pr(Boot) #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5                         #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4 7.7805      11     0.12 # }

what: Confidence Intervals for Model Parameters — confint.slca
title: Confidence Intervals for Model Parameters — confint.slca
text: Computes confidence intervals one parameters fitted model. Package slca adds methods slca fits.

title: Confidence Intervals for Model Parameters — confint.slca
code: # S3 method for class 'slca' confint(object, parm, level = 0.95, type = c("param", "logit"), ...)

title: Confidence Intervals for Model Parameters — confint.slca
text: object object class slca estimated. parm integer string specifying parameters given confidence intervals. level numeric value representing desired confidence level intervals, default 0.95. type character string specifying format results returned. Options include "probs" probability format "logit" log-odds (logit) format, default "probs". ... additional arguments.

title: Confidence Intervals for Model Parameters — confint.slca
text: matrix two columns representing confidence intervals selected parameters. columns named based specified confidence level (level): 100 * (level / 2) %: column shows lower bound confidence interval. 100 * (1 - level / 2) %: column shows upper bound confidence interval. level parameter specifies confidence level, common values 0.05 95% confidence interval 0.01 99% confidence interval.

title: Confidence Intervals for Model Parameters — confint.slca

title: Estimate Parameters of slca Object — estimate
text: Estimate parameters model constructed using slca function.

title: Estimate Parameters of slca Object — estimate
code: estimate(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'slca' estimate(x, data,     method = c("em", "hybrid", "nlm"),     fix2zero = NULL,     control = slcaControl(), ...)

title: Estimate Parameters of slca Object — estimate
text: x slca object defining SLCM model estimated. ... additional arguments. data data.frame object containing observed categorical variables incorporated model. method estimation method SLCM parameters. default "em", employs expecation-maximization (EM) algorithm estimation; alternative "nlm", utilizes nlm function Newton-Raphson algorithm. "hybrid" method begins EM algorithm concludes nlm function refined estimation. fix2zero vector parameters restricted zero. details restriction given 'Details' control list control estimation procedure. Used modify default values slcaControl.

title: Estimate Parameters of slca Object — estimate
text: object class slca estimated following elements: model list describing model. method method used estimation arg brief model description used estimation. mf data.frame used estimation. par log estimated paramters. logit log-odds estimated parameters. score score function estimated parameters. posterior list posterior probablities latent class variable. convergence logical indicator whether convergence achieved. loglikelihood loglikelihood estimated model. control control values used estimation process. returned object can processed using param functions extract estimated parameters respective standard errors. Additionally, regress function enables logistic regression analysis using three-step approach evaluate effect external variables latent class variables.

title: Estimate Parameters of slca Object — estimate
text: constrain certain parameters zero, use fix2zero argument. parameter associated unique index. can identify index specific parameter invoking param function index = TRUE argument. apply constraints, include relevant parameter indices fix2zero argument.

what: Goodness of Fit Test for Estimated slca Model — gof
title: Goodness of Fit Test for Estimated slca Model — gof
text: Provides AIC, BIC deviance statistic (G-squared) goodness fit test fitted model. Absolute model fit can tested deviance statistics, test argument specified.

title: Goodness of Fit Test for Estimated slca Model — gof
code: gof(object, ...)  # S3 method for class 'slca' gof(    object, ..., test = c("none", "chisq", "boot"),    nboot = 100, plot = FALSE,    maxiter = 100, tol = 1e-6, verbose = FALSE )

title: Goodness of Fit Test for Estimated slca Model — gof
text: object object class slca estimated. ... additional objects class slca estimated. test character string specifying type test conducted. "chisq", chi-squared test conducted. "boot", bootstrap test conducted. nboot integer specifying number bootstrap rounds performed. plot logical value indicating whether print histogram G-squared statistics boostrap samples, test = "boot". maxiter integer specifying maximum number iterations allowed estimation process bootstrapping round. tol numeric value setting tolerance convergence bootstrapping round. verbose logical value indicating whether print progress updates number bootstrapping rounds completed.

title: Goodness of Fit Test for Estimated slca Model — gof
text: data.frame containing number parameters (Df), loglikelihood, AIC, BIC, G-squared statistics, residual degree freedom object. Depending test argument, p-value corresponding statistical test may also included.

title: Goodness of Fit Test for Estimated slca Model — gof
code: library(magrittr) data <- gss7677[gss7677$COHORT == "YOUNG", ] stat2 <- slca(status(2) ~ PAPRES + PADEG + MADEG) %>%    estimate(data = data, control = list(verbose = FALSE)) stat3 <- slca(status(3) ~ PAPRES + PADEG + MADEG) %>%    estimate(data = data, control = list(verbose = FALSE)) stat4 <- slca(status(4) ~ PAPRES + PADEG + MADEG) %>%    estimate(data = data, control = list(verbose = FALSE))  gof(stat2, stat3, stat4) #> Analysis of Goodness of Fit Table #>  #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC     Gsq Res. Df Pr(>Chi)     #> stat2 21 -1179.2 2400.4 2489.5 115.979      53 1.34e-06 *** #> stat3 32 -1139.3 2342.6 2478.5  36.204      42   0.7226     #> stat4 43 -1135.4 2356.8 2539.4  28.423      31   0.5993     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 # \donttest{ gof(stat2, stat3, stat4, test = "boot") #> Analysis of Goodness of Fit Table #>  #>       Df  logLik    AIC    BIC     Gsq Res. what: GSS 1976-1977 Data on Social Status and Tolerance towards Minorities — gss7677
title: GSS 1976-1977 Data on Social Status and Tolerance towards Minorities — gss7677
text: dataset contains responses General Social Survey (GSS) years 1976 1977, focusing social status tolerance towards minorities latent class models can fitted using dataset replicate analysis carried McCutcheon (1985) Bakk et al. (2014).  data contains covariates including year interview, age, sex, race, degree, income respondents. variables associating social status include father's occupation education level, mother's education level, variables associating tolerance towards minorities created agreeing three related questions: (1) allowing public speaking, (2) allowing teaching, (3) allowing literatures.

title: GSS 1976-1977 Data on Social Status and Tolerance towards Minorities — gss7677
text: data frame 2942 rows 14 variables: YEAR Interview year (1976, 1977) COHORT Respondent's age  levels: (1)YOUNG, (2)YOUNG-MIDDLE, (4)MIDDLE, (5)OLD SEX Respondent's sex  levels: (1)MALE, (2)FEMALE RACE Respondent's race  levels: (1)WHITE (2)BLACK, (3)DEGREE Respondent's degree  levels: (1)LT HS, (2)HIGH-SCH, (3)HIGHER REALRINC Income respondents PAPRES Father's prestige (occupation)  levels: (1)LOW, (2)MIDIUM, (2)HIGH PADEG Father's degree  levels: (1)LT HS, (2)HIGH-SCH, (3)COLLEGE, (4) BACHELOR, (5)GRADUATE MADEG Mother's degree  levels: (1)LT HS, (2)HIGH-SCH, (3)COLLEGE, (4) BACHELOR, (5)GRADUATE TOLRAC Tolerance towards racists TOLCOM Tolerance towards communists TOLHOMO Tolerance towards homosexuals TOLATH Tolerance towards atheists TOLMIL Tolerance towards militarists

title: NLSY97 Substance Use Data — nlsy97
text: dataset containing substance use behavior National Longitudinal Survey Youth 1997 (NLSY97) three years: 1998, 2003, 2008. dataset focuses youth born 1984 tracks three substance use behaviors: tobacco/cigarette smoking, alcohol drinking, marijuana use.

what: Print Estimated Parameters of slca Object — param
title: Print Estimated Parameters of slca Object — param
text: function prints estimated parameters slca model accepting estimated slca object.

title: Print Estimated Parameters of slca Object — param
code: param(object, ...)  # S3 method for class 'slca' param(    object, type = c("probs", "logit"),    se = FALSE, index = FALSE, ... )

title: Print Estimated Parameters of slca Object — param
text: object object class slca estimated. ... additional arguments. type character string specifying format estimated parameters displayed. options "probs" probability format "logit" log-odds (logit) format. default setting "probs". se logical indicating whether standard errors (TRUE) parameter estimates (FALSE) displayed. index logical indicating whether include (TRUE) exclude (FALSE) indices estimated parameters output.

title: Print Estimated Parameters of slca Object — param
text: list containing specified estimated parameters standard errors se set TRUE. components list include: pi Membership probabilities root variable. tau Conditional probabilities latent class variables, represented uppercase alphabets considering measurement invariance. rho Item response probabilities measurement model, represented lowercase alphabets considering measurement invariance.

what: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
title: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
text: function performs regression analysis explore influence exogenous (external) variables latent class variables within estimated slca model. utilizes logistic regression employs three-step approach.

title: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
code: regress(object, ...)  # S3 method for class 'slca' regress(    object, formula, data = parent.frame(),    imputation = c("modal", "prob"),    method = c("naive", "BCH", "ML"), ... )

title: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
text: object object class slca estimated ... additional arguments. formula formula defining regression model, including latent class variables estimated model exogenous (external) variables. data optional data frame containing exogenous variables interest. imputation imputation method imputing (assigning) latent class variables. Possible values : "modal": Assigns individual latent class highest posterior probability. "prob": Assigns classes individuals randomly according distribution posterior probabilities. method method used adjust bias three-step approach, options including "naive", "BCH", "ML".

title: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
text: list following components: coefficients matrix regression coefficients representing odds ratios class baseline class (last class). std.err matrix standard errors corresponding regression coefficients. vcov calculated variance-covariance matrix regression coefficients. dim dimensions coefficients matrix. ll log likelihood regression model. Using summary function, can print coefficients, standard errors, corresponding Wald statistics, p-values statistics.

title: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
text: Vermunt, J. K. (2010). Latent Class Modeling Covariates: Two Improved Three-Step Approaches. Political Analysis, 18(4), 450–469. http://www.jstor.org/stable/25792024

title: Regress Exogenous Variables on Latent Variables — regress
code: library(magrittr) names(nlsy97) #>  [1] "SEX"     "RACE"    "ESMK_98" "FSMK_98" "DSMK_98" "HSMK_98" "EDRK_98" #>  [8] "CDRK_98" "WDRK_98" "BDRK_98" "EMRJ_98" "CMRJ_98" "OMRJ_98" "SMRJ_98" #> [15] "ESMK_03" "FSMK_03" "DSMK_03" "HSMK_03" "EDRK_03" "CDRK_03" "WDRK_03" #> [22] "BDRK_03" "EMRJ_03" "CMRJ_03" "OMRJ_03" "SMRJ_03" "ESMK_08" "FSMK_08" #> [29] "DSMK_08" "HSMK_08" "EDRK_08" "CDRK_08" "WDRK_08" "BDRK_08" "EMRJ_08" #> [36] "CMRJ_08" "OMRJ_08" "SMRJ_08" nlsy_jlcpa %>% regress(smk98 ~ SEX, nlsy97) #> Coefficients:      #> class  (Intercept)  SEXFemale #>   1/3  -0.6614       0.0804   #>   2/3   0.3983      -0.4445   nlsy_jlcpa %>% regress(drk98 ~ SEX, nlsy97) #> Coefficients:      #> class  (Intercept)  SEXFemale #>   1/3  -0.0676       0.5571   #>   2/3  -0.1342      -0.2022   nlsy_jlcpa %>% regress(mrj98 ~ SEX, nlsy97) #> Coefficients:      #> class  (Intercept)  SEXFemale #>   1/3  -1.517       -0.196    #>   2/3  -1.099        0.390    # \donttest{ nlsy_jlcpa %>% regress(use98 ~ SEX, nlsy97) #> Coefficients:      #> class  (Intercept)  SEXFemale #>   1/5  -1.8177       0.0329   #>   2/5  -2.5109       0.8061   #>   3/5  -0.8806       0.0449   #>   4/5  -0.3137       0.5978   nlsy_jlcpa %>% regress(prof ~ SEX, nlsy97) #> Coefficients:      #> class  (Intercept)  SEXFemale #>   1/4   0.3254      -0.0304   #>   2/4  -0.1178      -0.3801   #>   3/4   0.4083      -0.0635   # }

what: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
title: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
text: function constructs structural latent class model (SLCM) specified latent class variables.

title: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
code: slca(formula = NULL, ..., constraints = NULL)

title: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
text: formula formula specifying latent structure. Detailed model specification provided 'Details'. ... additional formulae defining model structure. constraints list constraints maintaining measurement invariance. Detailed explanation applying constraints available 'Details'.

title: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
text: object class slca containing various components model: tree: data.frame details parent-child relationships among latent class manifest variables. latent: data.frame listing latent class variables details . measure: data.frame describes measurement model. struct: data.frame details structural model. object prints model description four part. Latent variables: lists latent class variables incorporated model, along number classes variable. root variable marked asterisk (*). Measurement model: Shows manifest indicators latent class variable indicates measurement constraints (lowercase letters signify consistency). Structural model: Describes conditional dependencies latent class variables. Dependency constraints: Outlines constraints applied conditional dependencies latent class variables. column marked uppercase alphabet symbolizes consistent dependency structure.

title: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
text: formula can broadly categorized three main types, serving distinct purpose: Defining Latent Class Variables Manifest Indicators: Specify relationship latent class variable manifest indicators. example: Defining Latent Class Variables Manifest Indicators: Specify relationship latent class variable manifest indicators. formulas, latent class variable, denoted square brackets parentheses indicating number classes, left-hand-side (lhs) manifest indicators specified right-hand-side (rhs). example, formulas, k denotes number latent classes variable. Relating Latent Class Variables : Define relationships one latent class variable influenced another. subsequent example implies LC2 conditionally affected based LC1. Defining higher-level latent class variable: Identify latent class variables latent class variables rather manifest indicators. Following example suggests P measured LC1, LC2, LC3 – latent class variables. types formula, variables specified left-hand side (lhs) influence right-hand side (rhs). constraints parameter allows enforce specific conditions model ensure precise inference. instance, Longitudinal Latent Class Analysis (LTA), imperative latent class variables across various time-points convey identical meanings. constraints option, users can uphold measurement invariance measurement structural components model. Measurement Invariance Measurement Model: Ensures probabilities associated latent class variables consistent, thus maintaining semantic meaning across classes. command ensures variables LC1, LC2, LC3 semantically consistent. Measurement invariance structural model: Applies constraints within structural model ensure consistent interpretations transition probabilities. command implies transition probabilities P LC1 P LC2 consistent.
code: LC1[k] ~ x1 + x2 + x3 LC2[k] ~ y1 + y2 + y3 LC3(k) ~ z1 + z2 + z3 LC1 ~ LC2 P[k] ~ LC1 + LC2 + LC3 c("LC1", "LC2", "LC3") c("P ~ LC1", "P -> LC2")

title: Construct Structural Latent Class Model — slca
code: # Standard LCA slca(lc[3] ~ y1 + y2 + y3) #> Structural Latent Variable Model #>  #> Latent variables (Root*):            #>  Label: lc* #> nclass: 3   #>  #> Measurement model:                         #>  lc -> { y1, y2, y3 }  a # Latent transition analysis (LTA) slca(l1[3] ~ y11 + y21 + y31,      l2[3] ~ y12 + y22 + y32,      l1 ~ l2) #> Structural Latent Variable Model #>  #> Latent variables (Root*):               #>  Label: l1* l2 #> nclass: 3   3  #>  #> Measurement model:                            #>  l1 -> { y11, y21, y31 }  a #>  l2 -> { y12, y22, y32 }  b #>  #> Structural model:              #>  l1 -> { l2 } #>  #> Dependency constraints: #>  A        #>  l1 -> l2 # LTA with measurement invariance slca(l1[3] ~ y11 + y21 + y31,      l2[3] ~ y12 + y22 + y32,      l1 ~ l2, constraints = c("l1", "l2")) #> Structural Latent Variable Model #>  #> Latent variables (Root*):               #>  Label: l1* l2 #> nclass: 3   3  #>  #> Measurement model:                            #>  l1 -> { y11, y21, y31 }  a #>  l2 -> { y12, y22, y32 }  a #>  #> Structural model:              #>  l1 -> { l2 } #>  #> Dependency constraints: #>  A        #>  l1 -> l2 # Joint latent class analysis slca(lx[3] ~ x1 + x2 + x3, ly[3] ~ y1 + y2 + y3,      lz[3] ~ z1 + z2 + z3, jc[3] ~ lx + ly + lz) #> Structural Latent Variable Model #>  #> Latent variables (Root*):                     #>  Label: lx ly lz jc* #> nclass: 3  3  3  3   #>  #> Measurement model:                         #>  lx -> { x1, x2, x3 }  a #>  ly -> { y1, y2, y3 }  b #>  lz -> { z1, z2, z3 }  c #>  #> Structural model:                      #>  jc -> { lx, ly, lz } #>  #> Dependency constraints: #>  A        B        C        #>  jc -> lx jc -> ly jc -> lz # Latent class profile analysis (with measurement invariance) slca(l1[3] ~ x1 + x2 + x3, l2[3] ~ y1 + y2 + y3,      l3[3] ~ z1 + z2 + z3, pf[3] ~ lx + ly + lz,      constraints = c("l1", "l2", "l3")) #> Structural Latent Variable Model #>  #> Latent variables (Root*):                        #>  Label: l1* l2* l3* pf* #> nclass: 3   3   3   3   #>  #> Measurement model:                         #>  l1 -> { x1, x2, x3 }  a #>  l2 -> { y1, y2, y3 }  a #>  l3 -> { z1, z2, z3 }  a #>  pf -> { lx, ly, lz }  b

Default 1e-8. init.param initial parameters. nrep number trials. Default 1. test.iter integer specifying maximum number iterations allowed testing parameters. Default 200 na.rm logical value indicating whether remove observations including missing values (NA) verbose logical value indicating whether display progress updates estimation process
